title: Adding link to R reference manual
body:
Builds the PDF from mxnet/R-package, puts it in api/r, links to it from api/r/index. I checked that I can get to the pdf from http://localhost:8008/api/r/mxnet-r-...pdf

Dependencies needed on build server are R and LaTeX. If you're using apt you can apt-get install r-base, no other R packages are required. And also a LaTeX distribution is required.

I didn't change the Dockerfile in mxnet/docs since that would require installing LaTeX which would greatly increase the image size (~3 GB for basically no benefit). 

(Also, fixed the r tutorials link to http://mxnet.io/tutorials/index.html#r-tutorials)

title: Better error messaging when infer_shape fails
body:
Previously, when infer_shape failed, it would show the difference between the provided and inferred shapes for gradients, gradient-arguments, gradient-values, or aux-states, but NOT plain arguments.  I fixed that so it shows the full error message for normal arguments too.

So previously you'd just see:
```
mxnet.base.MXNetError: InferShape Error in loss's label argument
```

Now it shows:
```
mxnet.base.MXNetError: InferShape Error in loss's label argument
Shape inconsistent, Provided=(50,1024), inferred shape=(50,100)
```

(Also just removed an extra space in the "shape inconsistent" message to make it display a bit more cleanly.)

Also, I added a bit of python code to print the arguments passed in to infer_shape() in case of failure -- to further help with debugging infer_shape problems.

title: R doc changes
body:
Small changes:
-Removing useless lines from R vignettes.
-Fixing link for http://mxnet.io/tutorials/index.html#r-tutorials

Bigger change:

Adding an R reference manual (https://github.com/andremoeller/mxnet/blob/r-doc-changes/docs/api/r/mxnet-r-reference-manual.pdf). This reference manual was generated from /R-package using rd2pdf. The Makefile has a line to copy the pdf into the HTML tree so it's hosted at mxnet.io/api/r/mxnet-r-reference-manual.pdf.

Ideally the PDF would be built in the sphinx doc build rather than being added to the repo, but I'm not sure how to manage the R dependencies to do this with Sphinx. At any rate this seems like a decent interim measure so R has some API doc support in the short run -- better than nothing, I suppose.

Alternative solutions welcome.

title: Improve Python API reference
body:
WHatever system renders the python class docstrings into HTML is failing in some cases because there isn't a blank line between the class description and the line that says "Parameters\n----------".  The result is e.g. http://mxnet.io/api/python/io.html#mxnet.io.NDArrayIter where the description writes out the list of parameters in paragraph form like "Taking NDArray or numpy array to get dataiter. :param data: NDArrayIter supports single or".  

This change just adds blank lines to a bunch of docstrings, and should fix all these issues.

title: Better error messaging and some docs improvements
body:
A few changes to error messaging.  

In several places, python errors were just printing the string message of the exception, not the exception class or stack-trace.  Now it's printing the full stack-trace.  This is mostly in python operators.

In a couple of the C++ operators I've improved the error messages when checks fail.

Also a few comment changes which will improve the auto-generated API docs.

body:
Hi, I have add the inception-resnet-v2 in mxnet, and test in the 17flowers dataset, It's ok to be convergent. I think many people will be interested it. And In order to test it ,  is it ok to push the 17flowers binary files to the  [http://data.dmlc.ml/mxnet/data](http://data.dmlc.ml/mxnet/data). In big model network like googlenet, inception-resnet-v2, I think that the 32x32 or 28x28 images are not suitable to make a test.

And could anyone test this model in bigger DataSet like ImageNet. I have no enough resources to test it.

Thanks for such a good DL Framework.

repo.name: mxnet
repo.description: Lightweight, Portable, Flexible Distributed/Mobile Deep Learning with Dynamic, Mutation-aware Dataflow Dep Scheduler; for Python, R, Julia, Scala, Go, Javascript and more

title: Less redundant Reshape spec
body:
The core ability this gives is to allow certain kinds of reshape without requiring you to know all the dimensions up-front, in a more flexible way than the current codes 0 and -1. This make it easier for humans to express certain kinds of ops, but also makes it possible for machines to express certain reshapes without having to know exact sizes of irrelevant parts of the input. 

That's what I'm using this for our fork: helping our neural network framework unroll recurrent networks more easily and efficiently. You typically can prove ahead of time that an unrolling algorithm is correct, and for speed reasons you do NOT want to track tensor dimensions during unrolling at run-time. But Reshape layer demands to know all tensor sizes even when the desired resize operation doesn't actually depend on them.

So this PR adds 3 more codes to Reshape that let it figure out more things itself:
* -2: copy all remaining dimensions from input shape to output shape
* -3: merge two adjacent dimensions in input shape
* -4: split a single dimension in input shape into two (where either one can be inferred if given the other).

It should be pretty straightforward to add more codes in future, like maybe a code for merging all remaining dimensions. 

These are documented formally in the description of "target_shape" with proper indices etc, the previous documentation was very vague.

Here's an example that illustrates all three: let's say you want to 'broadcast' an operation across a sequence by simply merging the sequence and batch dimensions together and then doing an ordinary batched op. That kind of merge op can be expressed as a Reshape with target `(-3, -2)` -- merge the first two dimensions, then copy the rest. After you apply the op you'll want to do an unmerge: which is `(-4,slen,-1,-2)`. Notice that the only static information we needed to know here was the sequence length to unmerge properly. The dimensions and rank of the inner tensors was not needed. 

Another example: any existing code will be able to replace any sequence of "0s" with a single "-2".

title: Add USE_MXNET_LIB_NAMING for DLL irregularities
body: Adding a (default ON) CMake option to activate dynamic library naming irregularities preferred by the MXNet project. This allows projects that rely on DLLs using standard file naming conventions to trivially suppress this behavior. This should have no impact on existing builds.

title: Modifying FindMKL to respect i386 and allow ILP64
body:
These changes should not impact the default behavior of the FindMKL module on 64-bit Linux platforms. The major change is that the gnu fortran interface is removed from the list of MKL dependencies when using `gcc`.

- Add MKL_USE_ILP64 to allow the ILP64 data model in MKL (off by default)
- Add the MKL_USE_CLUSTER option (disabled on 32-bit platforms as the functionality is unavailable)
- Limit the gf interface to instances where gfortran is used

title: add tutorial for class activation maps
body:
A demo script of the method proposed in "Zhou, Bolei, et al. "Learning Deep Features for Discriminative Localization." arXiv preprint arXiv:1512.04150 (2015)".

This method can automatically localize the discriminative regions in an image using global average pooling in CNNs.

title: Feature/instance normalization
body:
Implementation of the Instance Normalization layer introduced by [Instance Normalization:
The Missing Ingredient for Fast Stylization](https://arxiv.org/abs/1607.08022), and implemented by the authors [here](https://github.com/DmitryUlyanov/texture_nets/blob/master/InstanceNormalization.lua).

One question: I used the terminology "weight" and "bias" to refer to the learnable parameters. But perhaps they should be the same as used in batch norm (beta and gamma).

title: quick fix fcn-xs example
body:
this is a quick fix.

Due to the pool/conv shape is changed currently , so the fcn-xs example is broken, such as https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/issues/2925 https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/issues/3638 https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/issues/3634  
the reason for this issue should due to the shape before deconv is smaller than old-mxnet-version, so we just make the output shape of deconv bigger than before, i test in on fcn-32 training, and it seems ok.

repo.name: mxnet
repo.description: Lightweight, Portable, Flexible Distributed/Mobile Deep Learning with Dynamic, Mutation-aware Dataflow Dep Scheduler; for Python, R, Julia, Scala, Go, Javascript and more

title: Feature/pad
body:
A padding layer `mx.Pad` that supports flexible padding: 
- Each tensor dimension can be padded at the start and end (but only special case of 2d images is supported right now, ie padding only the last two dimensions of a 4-tensor).
- Two padding modes are supported at the moment: `"constant"` and `"replicate"`. `"constant"` pads with a constant value, 0 by default, with a custom value specifiable with the `padding_constant` option. `mx.Pad` with `"constant"` pad mode is equivalent to [tf.pad](https://www.tensorflow.org/versions/r0.11/api_docs/python/array_ops.html#pad) with `mode='CONSTANT'`. `"replicate"` pads with the tensor boundary values, and is equivalent Torch [SpatialReplicationPadding](https://github.com/torch/nn/blob/master/doc/convolution.md#nn.SpatialReplicationPadding) for the special case of image padding. The implementation was adapted from Torch.

A general implementation will need to be added later.

Also note: `atomicAdd` was overloaded for `double` and `fp16` types. The latter needs to be carefully checked.
